The Secretary of Stats for Foreign affairs informed the Cabinet that, after examining thequestion in the Foreign Office, - he agreed tothe proposals of the Acting Secretary o^ Statefor War for the withdrawal from China of the4th Light Brigade, Royal Artillery, now at hong-Dong.The Secretary of State for Scotland(acting for the Secretary of State for War)said that the Chief of the Imperial GeneralStaff had admitted that the Artillery Brigademight be useful if a military operation such asthe re-capture of the British Concession at hankow should become necessary. They/7 had assumed xshat such an operation was unlikely,and in any event they did not regard the Brigadeas essential.The Cabinet agreed That the Secretary of State for'War should have authority towithdraw from China the 4thLight Brigade, Royal Artillery,now in Hong-Kong, THE PROROGA-TION OPPARLIAMENT .The FingrsSpeech.(previous reference:Cabinet 51(27), Ocn-clusior. 6.)2. The Cabinet had before them a first draftof the King'8 Speech on the Prorogation ofParliament, December, 1927 (Paper C.p.-315 (27)).After examining the draft of the King'sSpeech clause by clause, the Cabinet decidedas follows:-(a) The first clause on page 1 shouldbe re-drafted in accordance withsuggestions made by His Majesty."New Zealand""Australia",(b) In the first clause,should be put beforesince the Duke and Duchess of Yorkhad visited that Dominion the first of the two.(c) The second clause on the first page,dealing with visits of british ministers to the Dominions and india should be omitted.(d)(e)(f)The Secretary of State for ForeignAffairs should re-draft the refer-ences to foreign affairs (which hadbeen pr-pared before his return from geneva) ,arid include any new subjects which he might deem advisable: e.g.,the vfsit of the President of theFrench Republic, the visit of theKing, of Egypt, and the good results which it was hoped the latter visitmight lead to. Sir Austen Chamberlain'contribution should be inserted imme-diately a^ter the first clause onpage 1.The First Lord of the admiralty should prepare the draft of a clausedealing with the Geneva Naval Confer-ence, wnich should follow the material to be prepared by the Secretary ofState for Foreign Affairs,.The Secretary of State for india should consider a slight re-draftof the second clause on page 2,dealing with the Inquiry into theworking of the system of governmentin India, with a view to eliminating the words beginning in the fourthline from the botton , "There may be built up a sysof Government", etc(g)A reference to the Trade disputes act should be inserted. (h) The Minister of Health, should examine the first clause on page 4,relating to Housing, in order toascertain whether it applied to scotland as well as to England.(i) The Secretary of State for india should edit the revised draft ofthe Hing's Spesoh on behalf of theCabinet.(j) All suggested amendments should besent, in the first instance, to theSecretary of the Cabinet.(k) The re-draft of the Speech shouldbe circulated to the Cabinet as soonas convenient, and, if possible,before the end of the week; but,unless the Prime Minister deemsnecessary, no Special Meeting ofthe Cabinet should be held to revise the draft.-3- 3, The Cabinet had before their, copies of letters dated November 23 and December 1, 1927,from Colonel The Right Hon. John Gretton, M.P.,to the Prime Minister, in regard to the urgent need for substantial economy.in public expend!-ture, both national and local, during theforthcoming financial year (Paper C.P.-317 (27)).The Chancellor of the Exchequer took this occasion to make a full statement to the Cabineton the financial outlook as affecting the budget of 1928-9 so far as this could at present before seen. He indicated a probable gap betweenrevenue and expenditure as at present estimated by the Departments, which would have to be filled. After explaining the limitations onthe possibilities of additional taxation of a relatively uncontentious character, and emphasised- .sizing the importance of not increasing theIncome Tax, he outlined a concerted scheme of economies, spread over a number of Departments,some of which are already agreed to, in wholeor in part, and others of which he hoped wouldbe realised. He undertook to circulate particu-lars of these economies (which he gave to theCabinet in full) in a short Memorandum to hiscolleagues. He paid a special tribute to theefforts made by the Secretary of State for air and the Chief of the Air Staff for their co-operation in the reduction of expenditure.In the course of the discussion a proposal was made that during the coming financial yeara /meeting should be held of the Chairmen of theFinance Committees of Local Authorities, to be addressed by the Prime Minister, with a viewto obtaining some reduction in local expenditurewith the possibility of deriving therefrom somerelief in national expenditure.General satisfaction was expressed at thesuccess of the Minister of Pensions in his efforts to reduce expenditure without anyinjustice to war pensioners and with the minimum of friction.The Cabinet expressed their appreciationthat they had been informed of the serious diffi-culties in the financial situation while thereis still time to cope with them and to avoid the evil consequences.After further discussion, the cabinet agreed (a) That, in the present politicalsituation, it is out of thequestion to contemplate anIncrease in Income Tax for thefinancial year 1928-9, and that"every possible effort must be madeto achieve the economies requiredto balance the Budget either bythe measures proposed by theChancellor of the Exchequer or inother ways:(b) To take note that the Chancellorof the Exchequer will circulatesome particulars of his proposals: i -(c) That the Prime Minister should reply to Colonel Gretton to theeffect that the Government fullyrealise the importance of avoidingadditional expenditure and curtail-ing existing expenditure to theutmost realiseable extent, and areresolutely facing the problem.2, Ahit shall Gardens, S.W.1.December 15, 1927.
